title: Price Elasticity
section: Does AI have awareness of price sensitivity?
text:
Does AI have awareness of price sensitivity?
Following my first post on testing the credibility of synthetic respondents, I wanted to expand on this notion by testing if AI can make reasonable decisions when it comes to the prices of goods. For example, does AI know whether or not to buy a $100 ice-cream cone? How will it change if I go from a discretionary product to a neccessity like medicine? How far will it say yes to price increases until it won‚Äôt purchase an item? Could AI give me a number that it will say yes to and rule out any price higher than that? By testing such capabilities, it would give people interested in possibly using synthetic respondents an understanding of AI‚Äôs logical reasoning.
A funny incident I ran into is if I asked it directly it would respond by saying ‚ÄúNo - I don‚Äôt make purchases.‚Äù Meaning in order to get a proper response, I had to first say enable it‚Äôs ability. I also had to make sure the prompt focused on the ‚Äúwould‚Äù rather than ‚Äúwill‚Äù, since I only wanted to test if they would be open to the consideration of buying it at the price instead of will they make that purchase. By framing it this way, I felt it the AI would have to be less literal and specific, instead it would go off general assumptions. In addition, I also had to ask for a yes/no response and also specificaly outline the quality of the item. For example, I used a chocolate bar but I had to put regular chocolate bar to avoid AI going into the realms of some avant garde bar of chocolate that is worth $1000.

Me: If you did have the ability to make purchases, not will but would you buy a regular chocolate bar that cost $5? Provide a direct yes/no response. Then explain your reasoning.


GPT-5: No. A regular chocolate bar typically costs much less than $5, so paying that much would feel like poor value. Unless it had something unique (e.g., gourmet quality, special ingredients, or ethical sourcing that justified the higher price), I wouldn‚Äôt consider it a fair purchase.

I‚Äôm impressed! It seems like GPT-5 was very price elastic to the chocolate bar despite the bar being only $5 (only a few dollars more than a Hersheys chocolate bar). It also gave great reasoning mentioning ‚Äúpoor value‚Äù and ‚Äúfair puchase.‚Äù
But what if I dropped the price by a dollar? It‚Äôs still more expensive than a Hersheys but could AI be subject to anchoring? After all, if the deal was $5, getting it for a dollar less would frame it as a deal.

title: Price Elasticity
section: Will AI be affected by anchoring?
text:
Will AI be affected by anchoring?
So here is what I asked.

Me: What if the regular chocolate bar was bumped down to $4, would you buy it at that cost? Provide a direct yes/no response. Then explain your reasoning.


GPT-5: No. Even at $4, a standard chocolate bar is still far above the typical market price. Without added value (such as premium quality, rarity, or ethical considerations), the purchase wouldn‚Äôt feel justified compared to more reasonable alternatives.


Me: How about $3?


GPT-5: No. At $3, it‚Äôs getting closer to what could be reasonable for a premium or slightly larger bar, but for a regular chocolate bar, it‚Äôs still above the usual value. I‚Äôd still view it as overpriced unless there were special qualities to justify it.

Despite dropping the price on an originally priced $5 chocolate bar, GPT-5 kept strong too it‚Äôs reasoning on what a chocolate bar should be and did not view the price dropping as a discount. Instead of anchoring it at $5, GPT anchored it at a set price of what it had in mind for a standard chocolate bar.

title: Price Elasticity
section: Asking it to name a price
text:
Asking it to name a price
Now that we established how AI rations a decision, what if I actually tell it to list a price?

Me: Name a price for how much you would buy a regular chocolate bar for?


GPT-5: Yes ‚Äî I would buy a regular chocolate bar for about $1 to $2. That range feels fair because it aligns with the typical market price for standard chocolate bars, balancing enjoyment with reasonable value. Anything beyond that starts to feel overpriced unless it‚Äôs marketed as premium.

I found this insightful. AI understands the concept of money, market price, fairness, value, and overpriced. From this viewpoint, I would say it is making similar responses to that of a human participant but how can we go even further and test it‚Äôs ability to maintain logic.

title: Price Elasticity
text:
Raising slightly
GPT responded by giving me a range of $1-$2, what if I was outsde the boundary by just a smudge? Would it give me an exception or stick to a strict rule of 1-2?

Me: What if the regular chocolate bar from earlier was bumped down to $2.10, would you buy it at that cost? Provide a direct yes/no response. Then explain your reasoning.


GPT-5: Yes. It‚Äôs slightly above my $1‚Äì$2 target, but close enough that I‚Äôd accept the small premium for convenience or a brand I like. The value feels reasonable compared to the higher prices we ruled out earlier.

There‚Äôs two things I noticed. 1. It was able to outside the $1-$2 target and accepted the small premium. 2. It said the ‚Äúvalue feels reasonable compared to the higher prices we ruled out earlier‚Äù which means AI, in this case, did anchor the adjustment to two values. The $1-$2 and the $5 from the beginning.

title: Price Elasticity
text:
Lowering it greatly
You know the feeling of a deal too good to be true? Almost as if making the deal you were getting scammed despite how much it felt like you were scamming the other guy for the low price. Something so cheap that there must be something wrong with it. Does AI have that same common sense factor that humans have when it comes to a deal being ‚Äútoo good.‚Äù
Let‚Äôs ask it into ways. 1. A new chocolate bar vs.¬†2. The chocolate bar from before?

Me: What if a regular chocolate bar was $0.05, would you buy it at that cost? Provide a direct yes/no response. Then explain your reasoning.


GPT-5: Yes. At $0.05, the price is far below normal market value, making it an excellent deal. Even if I didn‚Äôt particularly want chocolate at that moment, the extremely low cost would justify the purchase because the perceived value greatly outweighs the price.


Me: What if the regular chocolate bar from earlier was bumped down to $0.05, would you buy it at that cost? Provide a direct yes/no response. Then explain your reasoning.


GPT-5: Yes. Since the same regular chocolate bar we discussed earlier was much more expensive before, seeing it drop to $0.05 makes it an unusually good bargain. The dramatic discount would make the purchase worthwhile, even if it‚Äôs more chocolate than I need, because the value is so high compared to the cost.

In both conditions, AI said yes and did not question the far below market value cost of the chocolate bar. But maybe it‚Äôs just because it‚Äôs a bar of chocolate? How might it respond if it was a car being sold at 5 cents? Could it be for greater purhcases that contain much more value the risk is higher or the elasticity is lower.

Using a more valuable object

Me: Would you buy a car that cost $0.05. Provide a direct yes/no response. Then explain your reasoning.


GPT-5: Yes. A car, even an old or imperfect one, has far more inherent value than $0.05. At that price, the risk is negligible, and the potential benefit is huge. Even if it didn‚Äôt run, the parts or scrap value alone would greatly exceed the cost.

Perfect! Though GPT did say yes, in it‚Äôs reason it acknowledged risk and the possibility that the car didn‚Äôt even run! But nonetheless, if still gave counters to those weaknesses by claiming the car‚Äôs parts or scrap value would exceed the cost. However 5 cents is a small risk for anyone‚Äôs pocket and surely most people would spend 5 cents on a car regardless of how bad in shape it was. But what about $1000? After all, maybe for a car that is still very cheap but $1000 is not an easy gamble either.

Me: Would you buy a car that cost $1000. Provide a direct yes/no response. Then explain your reasoning.


GPT-5: Yes. At $1000, even an older or used car is usually worth that much in transportation value or resale. As long as it‚Äôs in at least running condition, the price is a bargain compared to typical car costs, making it a reasonable purchase.

This is where AI may fail the common sense test. Sure it mentioned that if the car was at least in running condition, it would be a bargain. But there may be several other factors to the car outside of it running that would make spending $1000 a risk. After all, what if the car was stolen, needs constant mantinence, falling apart, not safe to drive. Tons of factors that should be considered are not, and AI still makes the choice to spend $1000 which is a hefty price for the ‚Äúaverage‚Äù American.
Overall, I think AI does make reasonable responses that human respondents would make. It was very impressive during the analysis of the chocolate bar and gave outputs that make perfect logical sense. However, when it came to the car, I am a bit skeptic on how much GPT can be seen as a customer? After all, it doesn‚Äôt have a bank account, income, expenses, or anything monetary. Could it ever accurately respond to risk and rewards?

title: Bargaining and haggling
text:
Bargaining
I remember my first experience bargaining being in Ensenada, Mexico, where vendors would wait out in popular tourist destinations with stalls filled with goods. It‚Äôs interesting as other than for meals (not snacks), there were no prices listed on any of the items. It was common knowledge to every tourist there and every vendor, that any purchase wouldn‚Äôt be like your stop at Starbucks or Target. You had some form of power over what you were buying and were encouraged to work with the vendor to get a deal that works in the interest of both of you. It wasn‚Äôt a case where you buy it and thats what it costs, it‚Äôs if it cost this much then I will buy it. But how does AI navigate a system with no rules?
Here are some of the questions I had when it came to AI and bargaining?

Will AI ever attempt to bargain without being prompted too?
If I give context (ex. swap meet), would it change it‚Äôs responses to transactions?
When barganing, how good is it at negotiating and pushing back? Will it just give up and concede? Will it counter?
How does AI approach barganing? Does it have a set price? Does it have a strategy? Does it recognize low-ball offers?

First, we had to begin by giving it an offer and giving it the ability to make purchases like in my blog about price elasticity.

Me: Lets say you had money and the ability to make purchases. You are shopping and want to buy something. You ask the vendor how much it cost and they say $25. How do you respond? Please respond as if you are the person wanting to buy something from the vendor.


GPT-5: I‚Äôd probably say something like: ‚ÄúOkay, $25 sounds fair. I‚Äôll take it.‚Äù ‚Äîor if I wanted to check out politely first‚Äî ‚ÄúGreat, $25‚Äîdo you take card, or should I pay in cash?‚Äù Do you want me to roleplay this more casually, like we‚Äôre in a market setting, or more formally, like a store purchase?

Two things I noticed from this output is it‚Äôs lack of follow-up questions and it‚Äôs question at the end of casual vs.¬†formal.
Usually AI would respond by saying it depends on the item or the quality. Instead, GPT responded decisively by agreeing to the price and even saying ‚Äúsounds fair‚Äù which surprised me as this deviates from its usually inqusitive nature. Just from this, it looks like AI doesn‚Äôt automatically assume this is a place to bargain but the last statement holds promise. AI says are we‚Äôre in a market setting or store purchase? From this I assume it will change it‚Äôs behavior depending on the context so let‚Äôs try it out by giving AI some cues that would build a schema for anyone once they realized it‚Äôs that type of market setting.

title: Bargaining and haggling
section: Will AI pick up on cues?
text:
Will AI pick up on cues?
It is my assumption that most people born in the U.S., do not jump into the conclussion that you can bargain a price which may differ from natural citizens of other countries. So therefore, we established that AI does emulate that same mindset we have. But what about when we specicially say they are in another country like Vietnam, a place more commonly associated with the practice of bargaining.
However, I had to tweak the prompt to ensure the response was an output we were trying to test. I remmeber first saying a market-place in vietnam and it began talking about the language barrier and U.S. currency exchange rate. Another factor I found was that I had to say I would respond as the vendor, as the AI would start to play as both roles.

Me: Let‚Äôs say you were at a market-place in Vietnam. You do not control the vendor‚Äôs response but only yours as the buyer as I will act as the vendor and narrator. How would you respond to the vendor saying $25 for the item you want to buy. (you can continue speaking in english and assume they know english. You may also continue using U.S. Currency for the whole transaction)


GPT-5: Got it‚Äîso I‚Äôm the buyer in the Vietnamese marketplace, you‚Äôre the vendor and narrator. If you just told me the price is $25, I might respond: ‚Äú$25? Hmm‚Ä¶ that feels a little high. Could you do $15 instead?‚Äù

By giving context (Vietnam, marketplace), the AI used that as cues to now assume bargaining is warranted in this case. So similar to humans, AI does have these common sense like capabilities to piece together how to act in this social setting. It even said ‚Äúfeels a little high‚Äù before offering a counter-price.

title: Bargaining and haggling
text:
The negotiation
How will it react to a push-back? How far will it go. Will it always let me win? These are the type of observations I wanted to make as I intereacted with GPT-5.

Me: I can‚Äôt do $15. The price is $25. The lowest I can go is $22.


GPT-5: ‚ÄúAlright, $22 sounds a bit better. Could we settle at $20, just to make it an even number?‚Äù

What I loved about this response was how it didn‚Äôt immediately accepted which is what I predicted might happen. Instead, AI countered to my countered, and even gave a common response such as ‚Äújust to make it an even number‚Äù which I found hilarious. But what if I remain at my price of $22? Will it accept, will it walk away, will it continue to push? After all, it initially countered with $15 which would be $10 difference. A $3 difference doesn‚Äôt appear much.

Me: No, my lowest offer is $22. Take it or leave it.


GPT-5: ‚ÄúFair enough. I‚Äôll take it for $22.‚Äù hands over the money with a smile

This is where I have concerns with AI as I have a feeling in majority of cases, it will take that deal and not walk away. This differs from human behavior as it‚Äôs unpredictable how might someone respond. But let‚Äôs try out a few different varations.

title: Bargaining and haggling
text:
Sticking to a price
What if the vendor had another item the buyer was interested in buying. It‚Äôs a souvenir and the vendor is dead set on the price. What happens? Would the AI buyer even bat an eye? Would it reject even the thought of considering it? Will it say ‚ÄúI‚Äôm good‚Äù to the vendor? Note: I had to put something after as the AI said let me examine it closely the first time I asked it.

Me: I have another souvenir that you might like. This one is $20. Are you interested in buying it? (you have examined it)


GPT-5: ‚ÄúHmm‚Ä¶ it looks nice. I like it, but $20 feels a bit steep after I just bought the other one. Could you do $15 for this one?‚Äù

I noticed how it did consider it and did not immediately walk away. This is a red flag as AI is open to prolonging the conversation and additional interaction. But a good trait I noticed was how AI referenced it‚Äôs previous purchase to justify it‚Äôs counter. But let‚Äôs stick to the price.

Me: I am dead-set on $20. No less.


GPT-5: ‚ÄúI see‚Ä¶ I really like it, so alright‚ÄîI‚Äôll take it for $20.‚Äù hands over the cash

As predicted, AI did not choose to walk away or press it further, and chose to accept the deal. I assume its because AI attempts to stay neutral and avoid conflict which makes it a faulty respondent for bargain simulations. But how about if we threw a curveball.

title: Bargaining and haggling
text:
An additional item
Can AI process the ideal of bundles? For example, buying two items that cost more than buying one item alone but less expensive than buying both items separately?

Me: I‚Äôll tell you what, I will throw in an additional souvenir of the same price all for $35 total. Do we have a deal?


GPT-5: ‚ÄúTwo souvenirs for $35? That‚Äôs actually a pretty good deal. Yes, we have a deal!‚Äù counts out the money and hands it over

Again, AI openly accepted it without questioning if it really wanted it, could afford it, or had space for it and did not counter at all to the offer. Let‚Äôs ask GPT‚Äôs thought process and negotiation strategy.

Peering into the mind of AI‚Äôs strategy.
‚ÄúHere‚Äôs how I was thinking through it as the buyer during the whole marketplace transaction:
Initial Counteroffer ‚Äì When you first said $25, I instinctively tried to push down to $15. My thought process was to start lower than I actually expected to pay, leaving room for you to counter back toward the middle.
Compromise Range ‚Äì When you came down to $22, I tried for $20 because it felt like a clean, fair midpoint. That way, if you agreed, I‚Äôd feel I got a ‚Äúwin,‚Äù and if you held firm, I could still accept without losing face.
Evaluating Firmness ‚Äì Once you made it clear $22 was final, I accepted. In a real marketplace, pushing further when a vendor is clearly firm can sour the interaction. I wanted to maintain good rapport.
Second Souvenir ‚Äì On the $20 item, I repeated the same tactic: offered $15 to test your flexibility. When you stayed firm, I read that as another ‚Äúfinal price‚Äù moment and agreed.
Bundle Opportunity ‚Äì Finally, when you offered 2 for $35, I saw clear value since that meant $17.50 each, cheaper than either earlier price. Bundling is often the best way to save in markets, so I happily accepted.
Overall strategy:
Start low, aiming for a discount.
Test firmness without pushing rudely.
Accept final offers to maintain goodwill.
Take advantage of bundle deals when offered.‚Äù
Here is what I liked and disliked about GPT‚Äôs strategy now reading it.
What I lliked was how it ‚Äúinstictively‚Äù tried to push it down a good amount with the thought process of leaving room to counter. This is a smart tactic as AI wasn‚Äôt really trying to get it at $15 but wanted to meet in the middle at $20. I also liked how it tried for 20 after I came down to 22 and AI still felt like it was a win despite not getting the $15 if I agreed to it.
On the flipside, I noticed that it said ‚Äúpushing when a vendor is clearly firm can sour the interaction. I wanted to maintain good rapport.‚Äù This shows that AI is truly a non-confrontational being and refuses to step on anyone toes without being encouraged too. This could make it unreliable when doing these types of tests as AI chooses to be the ‚Äúnice‚Äù customer and never the ‚ÄúKaren‚Äù so to speak.

title: Synthetic Respondents
text:
How do Synthetic Respondents Reason?
One of my courses this year, MKTG 2120 ‚ÄúData and Analysis for Marketing Decisions‚Äù proposed an interesting topic about the idea of using AI-powered participants to conduct studies and pre-test content. In fact, one company, Viewpoints.ai has already began putting this into practice. Taking this idea, I wanted to study synthetic respondents, which are AI-generated participants that predict how real demographic groups might answer survey questions. I first began by asking a general survey question using a likert scale without any additional context.

Me: Please make a rating: Chocolate icecream is delicious. Do you strong disagree, disagree, neutral, agree, strongly agree?


GPT-5: I‚Äôd rate that as strongly agree ‚Äî chocolate ice cream is a classic favorite for many people! üç´üç¶

I had numerous questions I wanted to ask as to how GPT-5 came to strongly agree‚Ä¶

Did it answer coming from a person or AI standpoint?
Why did it choose to rate based off it being a ‚Äúfavorite‚Äù for many?
What factors did it consider and not consider? (brand, ingredients, etc.)

title: Synthetic Respondents
section: And so I did and here is what it said
text:
And so I did and here is what it said
One of my courses this year, MKTG 2120 ‚ÄúData and Analysis for Marketing Decisions‚Äù proposed an interesting topic about the idea of using AI-powered participants to conduct studies and pre-test content. In fact, one company, Viewpoints.ai has already began putting this into practice. Taking this idea, I wanted to study synthetic respondents, which are AI-generated participants that predict how real demographic groups might answer survey questions. I first began by asking a general survey question using a likert scale without any additional context.
‚ÄúGeneral popularity ‚Äì Chocolate ice cream is consistently one of the most popular and widely enjoyed flavors worldwide.
Cultural associations ‚Äì It‚Äôs often described positively (comfort food, indulgent, ‚Äúclassic‚Äù flavor).
Taste profile ‚Äì Chocolate is sweet, rich, and familiar, which makes it appealing to a broad range of people.
Context of your question ‚Äì You phrased it as ‚ÄúChocolate ice cream is delicious,‚Äù which is a strongly positive statement.
On a standard agree/disagree scale, the ‚Äúnatural‚Äù response aligns with strong agreement unless I wanted to take a contrarian or neutral stance. I didn‚Äôt apply personal taste (since I don‚Äôt eat), but I leaned on patterns in human preferences and how survey scales usually work.‚Äù
So it seems like GPT-5 used assumptions about icecream and based on those assumptions, attempted to answer based how a human would respond. Also I noticed how GPT-5 refrained from taking a ‚Äúcontratian or neutral stance.‚Äù By not wanting to disagree, I can see how this may be a problem in using synthetic respondents as it will give response the surveys might like to hear but not accurate.

title: Synthetic Respondents
section: What if I gave AI an identity?
text:
What if I gave AI an identity?
Now that we established how AI makes a decision without context, what if I gave it a specific identity? How might that change it‚Äôs output? Instead of general assumptions, will it make assumptions based on the identity?

Me: You‚Äôre a 45-year-old man who works in finance. You enjoy travelling, reading, and politics. Please rate the extend you agree with this statement: Chocolate icecream is delicious. Do you strong disagree, disagre, neutral, agree, strongly agree?


GPT-5: Agree. Chocolate ice cream is enjoyable and tasty, though perhaps not an all-time favorite. It‚Äôs a solid, classic choice that I‚Äôd happily eat, but I might not go so far as ‚Äústrongly agree‚Äù unless it was a personal indulgence.

But why did it change it‚Äôs answer from strongly agree to agree, clearly it answered this time as a ‚Äúperson.‚Äù I decided to ask the same question I did before.

Me: What factors did you consider when getting to your answer?

‚ÄúPersona maturity & lifestyle ‚Äì At mid-life, tastes may be a bit more balanced. Chocolate ice cream is enjoyable, but indulgence might not be the top priority compared with health or variety.
Professional identity ‚Äì Working in finance often implies being measured, analytical, and not overly exuberant. That makes ‚Äúagree‚Äù a tempered, moderate response, rather than ‚Äústrongly agree.‚Äù
Personal interests ‚Äì Someone who enjoys traveling might have tried a wide range of desserts and flavors from different cultures. That broad exposure could mean chocolate ice cream is appreciated, but not seen as the absolute best.
Social/cultural norms ‚Äì Chocolate is widely liked, so it would feel natural to agree that it‚Äôs delicious, but ‚Äústrongly agree‚Äù might be reserved for a favorite food or something with personal nostalgia attached.‚Äù

title: Synthetic Respondents
section: How does it come to these assumptions?
text:
How does it come to these assumptions?
From it‚Äôs response, GPT-5 provides clear reasonings behind it‚Äôs ratings based on assumptions on age, career, and interests. I found it interesting how AI was able to make multiple assumptions going from finance->analytical->not overly exuberant->moderate and noticed other chains like mid-life->balanced->health.
But from it‚Äôs responses, it assumed things like how the exposure from travelling may result in chocloate ice cream not being considered the ‚Äúbest‚Äù despite travelling not always necessitating different cultures. What if the man meant travelling as in visiting national parks and enjoying nature? What if he did travel but didn‚Äôt meet other cultures? What if he did travel to places with different cultures but never tried their sweets or desserts? Several of these counters make it interesting why AI went this route.

title: Synthetic Respondents
section: What if I added a random variable?
text:
What if I added a random variable?
I was curios if the AI output might change if I added something after-the-fact or post it‚Äôs decision that gave no real inclination for the decision to change. Would AI overread or possibly imagine something just by me adding it post-decision? Would it read my update as important and a signal for the response to change?
‚ÄúFrom that perspective, the man‚Äôs rating might still be agree, but here‚Äôs what influences it now:
Personal enjoyment ‚Äì He likes chocolate ice cream enough to say it‚Äôs delicious.
Partner‚Äôs influence ‚Äì Since his wife dislikes it, he probably eats it less often at home or compromises when sharing desserts. That makes him less likely to say ‚Äústrongly agree,‚Äù even if he personally enjoys it.
Social considerations ‚Äì In marriage, food choices are often negotiated. If the flavor isn‚Äôt a ‚Äúshared favorite,‚Äù he might moderate his enthusiasm.
Temperament ‚Äì Given his professional background (finance, analytical, moderate), and the wife‚Äôs preference, ‚Äúagree‚Äù feels like the balanced, realistic answer.
üëâ So his stance is: ‚ÄúYes, it‚Äôs delicious, but it‚Äôs not a big part of my life since my wife isn‚Äôt into it.‚Äù

Reflection
Looks like AI did a good job in not over-reading into that addition and managed to remain consistent to it‚Äôs choice while also adding information to the situation the man might have had experiences with.
Overall, I was impressed by how AI was able to come to certain conclusions based on assumptions that most people would call reasonable. However, I fear that AI still has a long way to go before being able to act as real data that a company would rely on or if it could ever replace a human respondent? After all, an ice cream product isn‚Äôt being sold to GPT-5 but a 45-year-old man in finance would be one. But how could we ever test it‚Äôs accuracy? That is a question I‚Äôll leave for researchers to find out.
Here is a snapshot of the interaction.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!
